title: 108_s2790
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" and involves the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" involves the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. If certain applications are withdrawn, the Secretary of the Interior will issue a certificate of bidding rights to the holders, representing the fair market value of the coal reserves. The relinquishment of all rights associated with the withdrawn applications will occur. The Mineral Leasing Act involves the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. The relinquishment of rights associated with the withdrawn applications will be effective upon issuance of a certificate of bidding rights. No further adjudication of the applications is required by the Secretary. SEC. 3. METHOD FOR DETERMINING FAIR MARKET VALUE. SEC. 3. METHOD FOR DETERMINING FAIR MARKET VALUE. This section applies to the issuance of a certificate of bidding rights under section 4(a)(2). The fair market value of coal reserves from withdrawn lease applications will be determined by a panel established by the Secretary within 30 days of enactment. The panel will consist of 3 representatives appointed for this purpose. A panel will determine the fair market value of coal reserves from withdrawn lease applications, consisting of 3 representatives appointed by the Secretary, the lease holder, and the Governor of New Mexico. The Secretary will contract a qualified coal reserve appraiser to assist in determining the value. The Governor of New Mexico appoints 1 representative to assist in determining the fair market value of a coal reserve. The panel may supplement information as needed and must submit their determination within 75 days of establishment. SEC. 4. ISSUANCE OF PATENTS TO RELINQUISHED PREFERENCE RIGHT LEASE APPLICATIONS. The Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land, including mineral rights, within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application. This is to satisfy the Navajo Nation's land selection rights and promote land consolidation and mineral development in northwest New Mexico. Additionally, a certificate of bidding rights must be issued based on fair market value. The Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for land, including mineral rights, within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application to promote land consolidation and mineral development in northwest New Mexico. The fair market value determines the certificate of bidding rights, which is enforceable in a mandamus proceeding. The fair market value determines the certificate of bidding rights, which is enforceable in a mandamus proceeding. SEC. 5. USE OF EXCHANGE BIDDING RIGHTS. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) allows for transferability and can be used as a credit against payments for Federal coal leases. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) can be used as a credit against payments for Federal coal leases, including rentals, royalties, and bonus payments to the Secretary. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) can be used as a credit against 50 percent of the amount payable under a Federal coal lease, with the remaining 50 percent to be paid in cash or cash equivalent. Any payment of a Federal coal lease obligation by the holder of the certificate of bidding rights is treated as money received under the Mineral Leasing Act. Any payment of a Federal coal lease obligation by the holder of a certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) shall be treated as money received under the Mineral Leasing Act. The payment shall be credited and redistributed by the Secretary, with 50 percent in cash or its equivalent distributed to the State where the lease is located, and the remaining 50 percent through a crediting of the bidding rights involved. The payment of a Federal coal lease obligation by the holder of a certificate of bidding rights is redistributed by the Secretary, with 50 percent going to the State where the lease is located and the remaining 50 percent through a crediting of the bidding rights.
